docs.lead_paragraph: BRACE yourselves. If you receive Social Security benefits or assume that you will one day -- Republicans and Democrats are about to barrage you anew with claims, counterclaims, promises and warnings about the fate of the retirement system. They will have a common theme: that the other side is seeking to embark the nation on a path that will leave the government unable to meet its obligations to the elderly.

headline.main: Lockbox or Not, Social Security's Ills Grow

docs.abstract: Richard W Stevenson column assesses Democratic and Republican claims and counterclaims about long-term financial soundness of Social Security and how it relates to federal budget and 2001 tax cut; says Republican approach of adding personal investment accounts to program will not by itself solve financial shortfall and that Democratic plan amounts to hoping for return to budget surplus; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration today proposed dropping a requirement at the heart of federal rules that protect the privacy of medical records. It said doctors and hospitals should not have to obtain consent from patients before using or disclosing medical information for the purpose of treatment or reimbursement. The proposal, favored by the health care industry, was announced by Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, who said the process of obtaining consent could have ''serious unintended consequences'' and could impair access to quality health care.

headline.main: BUSH ACTS TO DROP CORE PRIVACY RULE ON MEDICAL DATA

docs.abstract: Bush administration proposes dropping requirement at heart of federal rules protecting privacy of medical records; says doctors and hospitals should not have to obtain consent from patients before using or disclosing medical information for purpose of treatment or reimbursement; privacy rules were issued by Pres Bill Clinton in Dec 2000 and allowed to take effect last April by Pres Bush, to dismay of health care industry; hospitals and insurance companies claim consent requirement could delay health care; they praise administration's proposal as victory for common sense; consumer advocates and Democratic members of Congress denounce it as threat to privacy; proposal will be published in Federal Register, with 30 days for public comment; government will consider comments and issue final rule, with force of law (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration today proposed dropping a requirement at the heart of federal rules that protect the privacy of medical records. It said doctors and hospitals should not have to obtain consent from patients before using or disclosing medical...

docs.lead_paragraph: Buddhas gaze down on 57th Street. Hindu gods have moved in on the Upper West Side. In Chelsea a Tibetan sage will tell you all you need to know about your health, your chances for heaven and who not to marry. The whole town is being blessed and cleansed and feng shui-ed. It's Asia Week in New York. It always is, really. The city has a huge, dynamic Asian population; its museums hold fabulous Asian collections. And probably no place on earth has a firmer gut-level grasp of how varied a concept ''Asia'' actually is. (Say to somebody, ''How about an Asian meal tonight?'' and they'll look at you funny. You mean Chinese? Japanese? Indian? Thai? Korean? Tibetan? Vietnamese? Or what?)

headline.main: Asia Week, a Vast Concept Embraced This Year by Buddha

docs.abstract: Holland Cotter reviews Asia Week in New York exhibits, including International Asian Art Fair at Lincoln Center, Arts of Pacific Asia Show at Events Center and smaller shows at private galleries; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10. Now Playing ''ALL ABOUT THE BENJAMINS,'' starring Ice Cube and Mike Epps. Directed by Kevin Bray (R, 99 minutes). In this fast, violent caper comedy, Ice Cube and Mr. Epps reprise the hip-hop-era, Martin-and-Lewis routing they inaugurated in ''Next Friday.'' There are some funny bits and a few stylish action sequences as the pair, playing a roughneck bounty hunter (Ice Cube) and a motormouth petty con man (Mr. Epps), chase after stolen diamonds, a winning lottery ticket and an international cast of bad guys. But the light comic tone is marred by gruesome, sadistic violence, and the rabid materialism suggested by the title (which refers to $100 bills) has an ugly, cynical edge (A. O. Scott).
